name: Reversion - The Escape (1st Chapter)
description: It’s 2035 in Buenos Aires, or where Buenos Aires used to be. You’ve just woken up in a hospital, and you can’t remember anything. All you know is you have to escape and find out what happened to the city. And how to save it.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or later Processor: Intel Core™ Duo or better Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: DirectX 9 compliant video card Storage: 400 MB available space

reviews.review_text: I played A LOT of point and click adventures back in their glory days and even play some now and then. This game is bad. I know is free, but it is really bad.  I can't stand the voice acting, is so terrible I had to mute to keep playing.  The game is too slow one can get bored after the first couple of minutes, and the gameplay, inventory handling and plot didn't help at all. The game is short, but I'm glad it is, really.  I think the developer should remove the voices, really, just remove it. They should also use a 'run' feature to help speed the gameplay a bit and improve the gameplay mechanics.  I can't recommend this game, but maybe will play episode 2 if they improve it.

First of all the game is free. It is a point & click game. Relaxing game, no stress (except if you are going for the achievments, some of them can be tricky) Graphics are cool, the game has its own style of characters and art.  The only thing that I would like to say is that when you try to 'use' an item or go to your inventory and then do something with the items can sometimes be a little hard to figure out. Its not a big problem though. You will get easily used to it. There are 16 achievments in total. All of them are relatively easy to obtain. I wouldnt say that its 'too hidden'. Some can ofcourse be tricky, but they are pretty cool and clever as well. Like I said earlier: It is Free to Play, and in my opinion the game is fun just like 77% of the other steam reviews posted. It is definitely one of the better Point & Click games out there. Dont hesitate, go download it, grab a soda or whatever you prefer and play.

Reversion - The Escape isn't a bad little point 'n' click adventure game but it's just as well it's free since you can finish the 'game' below than 1 hours. For a free game, it has decent graphics, decent voice acting, and I can't really complain about its 1-2 hour length since it's just a part of what's supposed to be a larger game. If you really like adventure games then it may be worthwhile for you to check this out, if not the only other people who should even bother are achievement hunters. A nice point and click game. The game took me less than an hour to beat, most of the things you gotta do are common sense and are things anyone would do if you were in the guys situation. For a free to play short game the game was well worth my time and i was able to get easy achievements!

I don't reccomend buying this but if you get it for free, like one episode of it is now, go for it, it's not exactly fun, but you get a couple of achievements, and that's nice. Because even if you don't like it, you get those from it so it doesn't feel like you've wasted the whole time you were playing it. The voice acting is grating, but you can get around it by turning off the sound and putting on some subtitles. One other annoying thing was that there were so many interactable objects that did nothing (the broken window on the ground, etc.) that I thought could be used to actually do something. I mean, in point and click games, usually if you have the option to use something, it's because you need to use it, but there were a lot of things it implied you could more than look at but never could do anything with (or the cables in the toilet stall). That and having to wait for a hint made me feel like I was playing a facebook game. Also the hints don't recharge if you've switched tabs, which again is annoying. I'm pretty rubbish at point and click games so it might just be me that needed all those hints anyway. Which meant a lot of the time I was just clicking randomly, trying to kill time while I waited for the next hint to become available. Also if you're re-playing it for an achievement, you're gonna wish the text was skipable faster.

Okay this game looked interesting and since I like to play point&click games, I thought why not give a try. Boy am I glad that I did not pay a cent for this game because it would've been a huge waste of money if I'm to be truthful. You start in a broken down, war torn, old hospital as a man who has lost his memory of the passed 25 years and wakes up in the year 2035. There is little insight as to what has happened other than that this war broke out in Buenos Aires and a group of people took over. From there, you must go through a series of challenging but boring tasks to escape the hospital before the General can 'interrogate' you. However, once you escape the hospital with your fellow patient Victoria....the game ends. That's it. There's no detail as to when the next episode will be out and no new details as to what the heck is even going on in the storyline itself. After playing through the first time, I played through it a second time having known what to do, and found that it took my under five minutes. Quite frankly, I don't even care when the next episode comes out because if this one was any indication as to what the next one will be like, I don't even want to play it. If you're looking for an indepth point&click game with an addicting storyline and beautiful graphics, this game definitely isn't for you. Play at your own risk.

This point and click game is free perhaps because it's advertising it's sequel, but it's a decent short adventure and it even has achievements for collect. But the English voice acting is bad.

If the goal of a first chapter is to get the player interested in buying the rest, then this one has failed.   - Every adventure game has at least one obscure puzzle, but there's usually some kind of hint if you think about it long enough. The hint system is a good idea (as is it's time delay), but it seems like it's made the designer reduce the in-game prompting as to what to do next.  - There's a few animation glitches where the character ends up on the ceiling. The double click fast travel was a good idea, but I couldn't get it to work reliably. - Hitting the same option 7 times to progress the story is bad design. At least change what the character says so we know we're on the right track.  - Context dependant pick ups aren't a bad idea (the medicine was a good one) but when a nessecary item is next to something that we're literally told is useless (like a pile of trash) it's frustrating. - The voices and english are a little off. Since this wasn't originally in English, this isn't something worth marking the game down for, but I think I'd find it better with text only if I played the next part.   Lastly, there just isn't enough information on the setting to pique my interest. Something about an explosion and a coup? Everyone seems to avoid telling you things, presumably for the sake of a reveal later on, but the purpose of amnesia characters are to justify the big exposition dumps needed to catch the player up. There just isn't enough there for me to put money in and find out.

As an avid point-and-click adventure gamer from back in the day, there's a fine line that a developer should not cross. It's obviously to me Reversion - The Escape's language is not primarily english and it was translated, albeit poorly. The logic in the game is hardly intuitive and the puzzles are boring. The game will not run full-screen in a Intel 4400 mobile chipset without ridiculous flickering constantly so it has to be played windowed. The voice acting is absolutely horrible, how did you get a monotone news reporter to play the doctor? It pains me to say this but after struggling to comprehend this poor game for the past half hour, it's going to be deleted and not finished. Why would anyone want to pay money for Part 2 if Part 1 isn't worth finishing?

Reversion is a point-and-click 'escape' game (as indicated by the sub-title). If you were around in the dark ages of the internet you're probably more than familiar with these, being the go-to 'hello world' genre of choice for flash developers.   OK, awkwardly phrased intro done, let's get onto the real review. This game is horrible for a veritable smorgasbord of reasons.   We'll start with the plot. You play as 'Straight White Male' (hereafter referred to as SWM), a character completely devoid of personality who wakes up in a hospital room with amnesia. Yes, apparently we're still doing amnesia. After establishing SWM's amnesia we go on to learn that a civil war has broken out and that it is 20 years later than SWM thought it was. Apparently he's a time traveller too or something stupid like that. There's also a doctor, a love interest (sorry, 'woman') called 'Victoria' and a soldier, though everyone seems to be avoiding the word 'soldier'.   Since I got bored of the game very early on, I'm just going to guess the rest of the plot.     SWM and Victoria escape the hospital and join up with 'The Resistance'. Through a series of misadventures they work hard to bring down whatever the other faction is, as Victoria's heart warms to SWM (possibly due to his charismatic blandness), Eventually they kill Hitler or whatever and fall in love.    The voice acting. Oh god, the voice acting. Everything is flat and emotionless, the doctor being the worst offender. The pacing of the lines is horrible as well, there's no pause in between them so everything has this weird rushed feel, despite the lines themselves being slowly paced.  The dialogue itself is pretty horrendous as well. It's fairly obvious that it wasn't written natively in English : not in itself a bad thing but the translation has been done poorly. There are odd quirks in the subject matter as well, where it is painfully obvious that the characters are speaking around the plot in order to hide information from the player, so that they can find it out later on and be surprised.  As far as gameplay goes: it's a traditional point/click escape game. The puzzles don't make any sense so you have to just wander around all the areas at a painfully slow pace, clicking everything and combining everything with everything else. So in that respect it's pretty faithful to the genre.  In conclusion, don't.  Despite being free, I'd still advise you to spend your money elsewhere.
